isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 2000, 4000, 8000 - ELECTRONIC ENGINES, CUMMINS M11E AND N14E - OPERATION - ENGINE BRAKE SYSTEM WITHOUT HT OR MT ELECTRONIC TRANSMISSION

svcproc.title: ENGINE BRAKE SYSTEM WITHOUT HT OR MT ELECTRONIC TRANSMISSION

svcprocinfo.para: The ECM shares control of the Engine Brake system with the vehicle driver and the Antilock Brake System (ABS) if the vehicle is so equipped. The driver enables the engine brake with the On/Off switch (170).

With the cylinder selection switch (171), the driver can select two-, four-, or six-cylinder braking for the N14E engine and can select three- or six-cylinder braking with the M11E engine, according to driver preference and driving conditions.
The ECM will not allow operation of the engine drake if it senses any of the following conditions:

item.para: ABS system is modulating the brakes.

svcsubproc.title: ABS/ECM COMMUNICATION
svcsubproc.para: If the vehicle is equipped with antilock brakes (ABS), the ECM and the ABS controller communicate through the J1922 data link (535) with the ECM. If the ABS system senses wheel lockup may occur, it will modulate the tractor brakes. This is communicated to the ECM, which would then turn off the engine brake.
The ABS system is discussed in GROUP 04 - BRAKES in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.

svcsubproc.title: ENGINE BRAKE ON/OFF SWITCH (170)
svcsubproc.para: The engine brake On/Off switch (170), gives the operator control of the engine brake function, providing the parameters of the previously mentioned items in Engine Brake System Without HT or MT Electronic Transmission section, above, are within their set ranges.

With the key switch on, and the On/Off switch moved to the on position, a ground path is applied to ECM (320), terminal 5 and/or 28 depending on the position of the engine brake selector switch (171). From these terminals the path is circuit 24AF and/or 24AE, dash connector (3), circuit 24AF and/or 24AE, the engine brake selector switch (171), circuit 24AD, the engine brake On/Off switch (170), circuit 24-G/97-GA, connector (3), and circuit 97-GA/97-G to the ECM (320) common ground terminal 10.

svcsubproc.title: ENGINE BRAKE SELECTOR SWITCH (171)
svcsubproc.para: The engine brake selector switch (171) allows the operator to choose the number of cylinders involved in the engine braking process.

The selector switch is a two-pole, three-position switch. With the engine brake On/Off switch (170) in the on position, and the selector switch set in position 1, a ground path is applied to ECM connector (320) terminal 5. The ground path is as described in Engine Brake On/Off Switch (170) section above. This causes the ECM to send a signal to braking cylinders one, two, and three (M11E) or cylinders three and four (N14E) to be activated.

When the selector switch is set to the number two position, a ground path is applied to ECM connector (320) terminal 28. The ground path is as described in Engine Brake On/Off Switch (170) above. This causes the ECM to send a signal to braking cylinders four, five and six (M11E), or cylinders one, two, five and six (N14E) to be activated.

When the selector switch is set to the number three position, a ground path is applied to ECM connector (320) terminal 5 and 28. The ground path is described in Engine Brake On/Off Switch (170) above. This causes the ECM to send a signal to all the braking cylinders to be activated for both the M11E or the N14E engine.

svcsubproc.title: SERVICE BRAKE SWITCH (69)
svcsubproc.para: The service brake switch (closed with brake pedal released) serves both the cruise control and engine brake system. It is an air actuated switch that is closed when the brakes are released.Applying the brakes opens the switch.

When the brakes are not applied, a ground is applied to ECM connector (320) terminal 13. From this terminal the path is circuit 97AL, connector (3), circuit 97AL, connector (330), circuit 97AL, the service brake switch (69), circuit 97H, connector (330), circuit 97-GF/97-GA, connector (3), and circuit 97-GA/97-G to the ECM (320) common ground terminal 10.
When the brakes are applied, the service brake switch opens and the ground is removed from the ECM connector (320) terminal 13.

svcsubproc.title: CLUTCH SWITCH (376)
svcsubproc.para: The clutch switch serves both the cruise and engine brake system. The switch is a normally open switch, adjusted to be closed when the clutch pedal is in the released position.

When the clutch pedal is in the released position, a ground path is applied to ECM connector (320) terminal 4. From this terminal the path is circuit 97AH, connector (3), circuit 97AH, the clutch switch (376), circuit 97-GH/97-GA, connector (3), and circuit 97-GA/97-G to the ECM (320) common ground terminal 10.
When the clutch pedal is depressed,the clutch switch opens and the ground is removed from ECM connector (320) terminal 4.
